text: Blue hat.
All right.
I have two kids.

Being a mom is such a core
part of my identity and informs

everything that I do-- what I'm
studying, what I'm focused on,

how I want to make an
impact in the world.
It's me and my husband.

It all starts with
communication and partnership.
You always need to prioritize.

Honestly, it's not easy, but
it's been incredibly rewarding.

My mom got her
masters of education.

I think a lot about
the sacrifices

she made to pursue
this education

and work while raising me
and my three other siblings.
And so ...

why I'm here is for my
son, is for my family.

And my husband and I
have a great routine

of making sure we're
dividing duties

in the home and care for our son
with our work and our studies.

I knew that I was pregnant
on the very first day at HBS.

I had Colin over
the winter break.

I had my second
baby a month ago.

I did return to school
after three weeks.

I really value being in the
classroom based on the case

method, having
those discussions.

My husband and I are
both HBS students,

and there were moments when
we were really struggling.

Do my kids see me enough
and feel like I'm present?

Do I feel like I'm making
progress in my career?

Becoming a mother actually
gave me more clarity--

not choosing between
career and family,

but someone who is creating
space for both in alignment.

I think being a
working mom brings me

a lot of perspective
and empathy.

This is just going to strengthen
me as a business leader.

What is it that I want
to teach my daughter?

You don't want to
compromise on your family.
You love your kids.

You want to spend
enough time with them,

but you also want to make sure
you're pursuing your dreams
and fulfilling yourself.

To be the best mom out
there, you need to be happy.
